title.narrative: Girls' Advocacy Alliance Liberia

description.narrative:
SUMMARY The Girls Advocacy Alliance is a five year programme (2016-2020) that consists of Plan International Liberia and DCI-Liberia, together with local CSO partners. Through lobby advocacy, the programme urges government representatives, traditional and religious leaders, private sector agents and communities at large to adopt measures and improve the implementation of existing policies, in particular in relation to child marriage, sexual violence and abuse, equal access to post-primary education and entrepreneurship for young women.
Building upon the results of the Girl Power programme (2011-2015), the target areas of the Liberian country programme are Bomi, Lofa and Montserrado counties. Nonetheless, some of the programme’s advocacy efforts, particularly at government level, will have a national reach.

The GAA Liberia country programme will build upon the results of the Girl Power programme (2011-2015), which was implemented in the target geographical areas of Bomi and Lofa Rural Districts and Montserrado Urban District. Nonetheless, some of the programme’s advocacy and lobby efforts will have a larger, nation-wide, reach.

The GAA programme activities to be implemented by Plan Liberia were temporilay suspended due to capacity constraints experienced by Plan Liberia. With support of Plan Netherlands, these constraints have been addressed over the course of the past year.
The final beneficiaries are girls and young women living in the directly targeted areas of Bomi, Lofa and Montserrado Urban District.

Violence against children and women is a common issue in Liberia. Child rape and sexual offences are among the most commonly reported crimes in the country. Liberia has faced a civil war and situations of post conflict may exacerbate existing violence.
Gender based violence and discrimination are to a large extent caused by deeply entrenched discriminatory social norms and values. Adherence to traditional norms and practices is perpetuated by local traditional leaders. Also gender inequalities are enshrined in the dual system law of Liberia. The government has adopted laws and policies related to the prevention and elimination of sexual violence and child marriage but access of girls and young women to prevention, protection and response services remains weak. This is due to inadequate and ineffective implementation of relevant laws and policies as well as the prevailing discriminatory social norms and values.

title.narrative: COVID-19 prevention & response

Number of COVID-19 management processes in which government policy makers, UN agencies and NGOs have included young people's participation and/or respond to the young people's advocacy ask around the response to COVID-19

comment.narrative: Number of COVID-19 management processes in which government policy makers, UN agencies and NGOs have included young people's participation and/or respond to the young people's advocacy ask around the response to COVID-19

During the period under review, Liberia saw an increase in the number of GBV cases although the number of COVID-19 cases was gradually reducing in the country. GAA supported girls and young women to form part of a sustained three-day anti-rape protest. The anti-rape protest led to the President of the Republic of Liberia to declare rape as a national emergency. Additionally, there was a three-day working session with High profile government officials led by the President of Liberia and INGOs, NGOs, Women and Girls’ groups, Media. The outcome of the meeting was a road map for the prevention of rape in Liberia.
In support of the Government of Liberia’s roadmap for the prevention of GBV, GAA also collaborated with the Ministry Education to plan activities on safe school protocols and the prevention of GBV in schools. In addition to carry on awareness and distribution of flyers, posters and sticker in 30 school in Bomi, Montserrado and Nimba Counties, both electronic and social media will be used to disseminate these messages.
